title: Galapagos Islands airport becomes world's first to be run ENTIRELY on solar and wind power
text:
14 shares 3

The world's first 100 per cent eco-airport has opened for business.
Baltra Airport in the Galapagos Islands is run entirely on power gained from the sun and wind. And following the rebuilding, 80 per cent of materials used were recycled from the previous infrastructure.
The Ecuadorian airport has been hailed by environmentalists who are keen to preserve the Galapagos' eco-system in the face of increased tourism.
Scroll down for video
Baltra Airport in the Galapagos Islands was opened in 2012 and was heralded as a 'green airport'
Now the airport can rely wholly on power gained from the sun and wind for day-to-day operations
Galapagos Islands gets world's first 'green' airport title The islands were recently named as the best in the world by readers of a leading travel magazine and despite being nearly 600 miles from the coast of Ecuador, they are on the bucket lists of many travellers.
Boasting idyllic beaches, historic cities and rugged coastlines, these are the top 10 islands in the world, according to Travel + Leisure magazine.
Home to 18 main islands, this archipelago in the Pacific Ocean is also famous for its marine life and rare species of birds and plants.
Charles Darwin developed his theory of evolution while studying wildlife on the islands, which are home to marine iguanas, sharks, blue-footed boobies, sea lions and other creatures.
The move to 100 per cent solar and wind power will delight environmentalists on the islands
The Galapagos Islands have seen an increase in tourism as people choose to explore its beauty
The Galapagos Islands, nearly 600 miles west of Ecuador, is famous for its marine life and rare species of birds and plants
In 2010, Galapagos Islands was removed from Unesco's List of World Heritage in Danger. The UN agency was satisfied that Ecuador's government had taken steps to address threats posed by invasive species, unbridled tourism and over-fishing.
Speaking to Euronews , airport manager Jorge Rocillo said: 'The main thing is that it is a sustainable building, a public building that can balance technology and comfort for passengers without polluting the environment.
'This is basically the legacy we want to give,' he added.
The airport's commitment to a healthy environment was first documented in its opening back in 2012 when it became the world's first 'green' airport.
The rebuild incorporated 80 per cent of the previous materials used in the airport development
Airport manager Jorge Rocillo has told of how he hopes a 'legacy' can be set in the Galapagos Islands
